channel.title: Well lets take a look at it, Mr Gumby!
channel.description: Recent content on Well lets take a look at it, Mr Gumby!

item.title: Film development
item.description: Film Development A little tutorial for sam :p For developing Ilford HP5 with D-76 developer the Massive dev chart must be consulted! select the film and developer from the drop down menus. I like to use 1:1 dilution ratio so for one roll of 35mm HP5 film at ISO 400 the development time is 13 minutes. mix 150ml of water with 150ml of D76 solution and ensure the temperature is 20 degrees Â± 0.

item.title: Kalman Filter RLC
item.description: code.has-jax { -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; background: inherit !important; border: none !important; font-size: 100%; } The RLC circuit above can be expressed by the following equation $$ \ddot{I}_{L} = -\frac{\dot{I}_{L}}{RC} -\frac{I_L}{LC} + \frac{I}{LC} $$ The equation can be expressed as two first order differential equations using the following method. $$ x_{1} = I_{L} $$ $$ x_{2} = \dot{I}_{L} $$ so $$ \dot{x}_{2} = \ddot{I}_{L} = -\frac{\dot{I}_{L}}{RC} -\frac{I_{L}}{LC} + \frac{I}{LC} $$ and $$\dot{x}_{1} =\dot{I}_{L} = x_{2}$$ Replacing variables with state variables $\bf{X}$ $$\dot{x}_{2} = - \frac{x_{2}}{RC} - \frac{x_{1}}{LC} + \frac{I}{LC}$$ Using the formula below the derivative can be discretised.
